titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Oral History of the American Left: Radical Histories Collection OH 002
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Tamiment staff

editionstmt.p: This version was derived from OHALforw.doc

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit 2009-06-30T17:18-0400

did.unittitle: Oral History of the American Left: Radical Histories
did.abstract: The Tamiment Library at New York University established the Oral History of the American Left in 1976 in order to collect and preserve the memories of veteran activists. These interviews describe seven decades of Left politics from the 1910s through the 1970s. They document the full spectrum of left politics in the twentieth century: Socialism, Communism, Anarchism, Trotskyism, and the New Left. There are interviews with both leaders and rank-and-file activists.

bioghist.head: Historical/Biographical Note
bioghist.p: New York University’s Tamiment Library established the Oral History of the American Left (OHAL) in 1976. The purpose of this project was to expand the archive of American labor and radicalism through the creation of “living documents,” the memories of veteran activists. The idea was “to create an archive of recorded reminiscences by participants in trade union struggles, political organizations, and grass-roots political and cultural activity.” Paul Buhle was the Director of the project. Roger Keeran was Co-Director in the early years. Jon Bloom joined the project in 1977 and worked as an interviewer, coordinator, and fundraiser.

The project began with several years of varied interviewing supported by small grants from the Rabinowitz and Bronson Cutting Foundations. The New Jersey Historical Commission provided funding in 1978 to support a series of interviews on radicalism in New Jersey, during the 1930-1960 period. Later, Ruth F. Prago developed the idea for a radio series based on interviews to be conducted for the OHAL collection, and together with Pacifica Radio the project received a one-year grant from the New York State Council for the Humanities to conduct interviews with twenty-five women about radicalism during the1930s. OHAL received major funding in 1982-1983 from the National Endowment for the Humanities. With this support, Paul Buhle conducted a sweeping oral history of ethnic-immigrant radicalism, its press and fraternal organizations. The NEH grant also enabled OHAL to collect hundreds of hours of interviews made by filmmakers on American anarchism, the Hollywood blacklist, the Communist Party, the Columbia University student strike of 1968, and other subjects.

The project also produced seven issues of a newsletter, and the transcript of a two-day conference co-sponsored by OHAL and the Tamiment Library on the occasion of the opening of the Max Shactman Papers.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The tapes and transcript in the Oral History of the American Left collection came from a variety of sources. Most of the interviews were done by Jon Bloom, Paul Buhle, Bea Lemisch, and Ruth Prago. They cover many subjects including: immigrant/ethnic radicalism, labor, women's history, radical newspapers, fraternal organizations, and student radicalism from 1910s through 1970s. The earliest interviews were done with those men and women who could recall the 1910s -1920s. The effect of the Russian Revolution on the Left in the United States, the formation of social and cultural institutions by the "New Immigrant" groups of all Left political shadings, the history of Socialism and Anarchism, and the troubled early years of American Communism. A particular effort was made to interview rank-and-file or middle-level leadership activists. These women and men for the most part did not leave written records behind so their oral histories are the only historical record that is available. A number of these interviews focused on "radical women." Many interviews focus on the labor movement, particularly the needle trades unions and the early years of the Congress of Industrial Organizations.

The immigrant-ethnic interviews might be the most unique element of the collection. OHAL interviewed representative figures from the Jewish, Finnish, Slovenia, Greek, Hungarian, Polish, Italian, Ukrainian, Lithuanian, Japanese, Scandinavian, and Spanish Left. A handful of tapes recall the African American experience.

Several interviews are with participants in the Abraham Lincoln Brigade, who fought in the Spanish Civil War, as the U.S. component of the International Brigades, and several other interviews document related activities. Several interviews document the long tenure of Jasper McLevy, Socialist Party mayor of Bridgeport, Connecticut, 1933-1957.
Ninety-five percent of these interviews are on cassette tapes with accompanying indexes. The rest are transcripts without tapes. Information about format is noted in the inventory.

Notable interviewees include: Notable individuals interviewed include: Herbert Aptheker, Rosalyn Fraad Baxandall, Daniel Berrigan, Abner Berry, James Boggs, George Breitman, Rose Chernin, Malcolm Cowley, Samuel Darcy, Solon De Leon, Hal Draper, Raya Dunayevskaya, Melech Epstein, Lawrence Ferlinghetti, Hugo Gellert, Todd Gitlin, Martine Glaberman, Albert Glotzer, Itshe Goldberg, Louis Harap, Michael Harrington, Howard "Stretch" Johnson, Mary Kolehmainen, Meridel Le Sueur, A.B. Magil, Thomas McGrath, Ernest Rice McKinney, Clarence Norris, Paul Novik, Harvey O'Connor, Louise Patterson, George Rawick, Lester Rodney, Annette Rubinstein, Pete Seeger, Norman Thomas, Stan Weir, Myra Tanner Weiss.

Several group interviews or conferences were recorded pertaining to the following organizations: Catholic Worker Movement, International Labor Defense, Johnson-Forest Tendency, Matteotti Club, Medem Jewish Socialist Group, Socialist Party(U.S.), Southern Negro Youth Congress, Workers Party (1940-1949), Workers Party (1940-1949).

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The files are grouped into 1 series:

separatedmaterial.head: Separated Material
separatedmaterial.p: There is no information about materials that are associated by provenance to the described materials that have been physically separated or removed.

userestrict.head: Use Restrictions
userestrict.p:
Permission to publish materials must be obtained in writing from the:
Tamiment Library/Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives
Elmer Holmes Bobst Library
70 Washington Square South
New York, NY 10012
Phone: (212) 998-2630
Fax: (212) 995-4225
E-mail: tamiment.wagner@nyu.edu

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p:
Published citations should take the following form:
Identification of item, date; Collection name; Collection number; box number; folder number;
Tamiment Library/Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives
Elmer Holmes Bobst Library
70 Washington Square South
New York, NY 10012, New York University Libraries.

did.unittitle: A

Name: Alesh, Minka
Description: SNPJ (Slovenian Benefit Society), 1910- present; Haberdashery Union, New York and Chicago, c. 1910-20; Women's activities in Chicago; SNPJ and Socialist Party, 1910s- 1920s.

Name: Alvarez, Jose
Description: Origins of Spanish language Communist movement in Ybor City, Florida, 1920s- 1930s; community support of Communists and relation to surrounding communities, 1930s-40s; immigration from Spain, work in tobacco factories and activities of unions, 1920s-40s; Red Scare decimation of Ybor City Left, 1950s; meeting with Fidel Castro before Cuban Revolution, 1950s.

odd.head: General note
odd.p:
Transcript and index available
tape#: 2 U2A

did.unittitle:
Name: Amter, Vicky
Description: Communist Party, lower east side, N.Y., 1940s-1960s; conflicts with her father, a Socialist; experiences as Local 65 shop steward; Jefferson School; harassment and isolation of CP in the 1950s; reactions to emergence of the New Left.

Name: Aptheker, Herbert
Description: College radicalism in 1930s; MA thesis on Nat Turner; joining the Communist Party; status in academic life; Jefferson School.

Name: Aronek, Harry
Description: Immigration; political and cultural activities in New York Jewish community, 1930s-1950s.

Name: Aspitz, Jacob
Description: Los Angeles Jewish Left since 1930s; rise of anti-Nazi "front" across Jewish community and Communists' participation in it; isola- tion of Jewish Left during Cold War; literary interests and old age around Yiddishe Kultur Farband.
B

Name: Banach, Stanley
Description: Neighborhood background in Providence, 1950s; Army life in Vietnam and in Germany, radical influences; union activity at Electric Boat/Quonset Point, Rhode Island, organizing drive; union activity at Brown and Sharpe before and during 1982 strike; political philosophy and aspirations.

Name: Barnett, Eugene
Description: Industrial Workers of the World, Northwest U.S., 1910s; West Virginia coal miners at turn of century; becoming a unionist; lumber work in Northwest; repression in Centralia.

Name: Barry, Walter
Description: Boyhood and first labor experience in Endicott, N.Y.; Trade Union Unity League and United Electrical Workers District 4, Westinghouse Elevator plant, Jersey City, N.J., 1930s-50s.

Name: Baxandall, Rosalyn
Description: Background in New York Old Left; cultural awakening in Madison; political and cultural experiences in Madison, 1958-60s; beginnings of Madison's women's movement.

Name: Bazell, Bertha
Description: Born 1896; immigrant Jewish background; Workman's Circle; Communist Party, 1930s-50s in Coney Island, N.Y.; later Fall River, Mass.; harassment by the F.B.I. in the 1950s.

Name: Bell, Ray
Description: Socialism/communism, Spain in WWII NOT IN OHAL GUIDE

Name: Bennett, Fay
Description: College anti-war movement, 1930s; American Student Union; Keep America Out of War Congress, late 1930s; experience of con- scientious objectors during World War II; postwar work with National Sharecroppers' Fund.

Name: Bergen, Jack
Description: Bridgeport in 1910s; Depression and Jasper McLevy; SP in Connecticut state politics, 1930s.

Name: Bernard, John T.
Description: Mesaba Park Coop. Assn. tribute to John (Tribute to) Bernard, U.S. representative 1936-38; speeches by former Minnesota Governor Elmer Benson and others about Bernard's record in Congress; response from Bernard; music.

Name: Berrigan, Daniel
Description: Last interview before he went underground and then to prison; reflections on his activities during the 1960s including Catonsville incident.

Name: Berry, Abner
Description: Communist Party in Harlem, 1930s; Ethiopia Defense Committee; Unemployed Councils; Richard Wright and CP cultural policies; CP branches and organizers in Harlem; opposition to CP in Harlem.

Name: Beumer, Steve
Description: Family background in Indiana and political activities there and in Detroit, late 1960s- 1970s; Socialist Workers Party; experiences as bus driver and union activist in Detroit.

Name: Birnbaum, Martin
Description: Life and activities of Yiddish "proletarian poet"; childhood, immigration and literary work for New Yorker Volkszeitung, 1920s; friendship with Moshe Nadir; role of Left in Yiddish literary community, the group Proletpen; disillusionment with Communism and poetic realism, return to unrestrained lyricism.

Name: Birnbaum, Martin
Description: The meaning of the "sense of humor" in Yiddish literary work; Birnbaum's own sense of humor contrasted to that of Moshe Nadir and to that of Jewish popular culture.

Name: Blair, Fred
Description: Role of ethnicity in Communist Party of Wisconsin, 1930s-40s; support of Left from Polish sector dating back to 1880, support of other Slav groups from 1910s; role of Meta Berger in Wisconsin Party and Blair's ascendency to state leadership; unemployment demonstration in Milwaukee and influence on students in Madison, University of Wis- consin; increase of District membership with addition of northern Wisconsin; character of northern Wisconsin rural Communists; exodus of rural Communists from state, 1940s-50s; McCarthyism and decline of Communist support.

Name: Bloomfield, Norman
Description: Young People's Socialist League, 1930s; split in Trotskyism; Berkeley campus; work in shipyards.

Name: Boggs, Grace Lee
Description: Asian-American family background in Providence, R.I.; education and involvement in radical politics in New York, late 1930s; Workers Party and Johnson-Forest tendency, 1940s; Correspondence (Detroit, 1950s); involvement in the black movement with her husband, James Boggs; comments on C.L.R. James.

Name: Boggs, James
Description: Youth in the South; factory life in Detroit, 1930s-40s; Johnson-Forest Tendency; activi- ties in 1960s-70s.

Name: Booth, Paul
Description: Students for a Democratic Society, 1960s

Name: Borun, Fannie
Description: Political struggles within the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, 1920s; experiences on trips in the Soviet Union, 1930s; women and the Communist Party

Name: Boudon, Judy
Description: Immigration from Panama; Spanish immigrant community in New York, 1930s; office and factory work; America Labor Party; Communist Party, and women in the CP.

Name: Brandon, Thomas
Description: Workers' Newsreel and Film and Photo League, early 1930s.

Name: Brecher, Jeremy
Description: Students for a Democratic Society, 1962-65

Name: Breitman, George
Description: Unemployed organizations in New Jersey, 1930s; Socialist Workers Party, 1938-54 in New Jersey.

Name: Brier, Harry
Description: East End of London, 1920s-30s; Jewish character of Communist support; anti- fascist activities in London, 1920-30s; immigration to Los Angeles and union activities, 1940s-present.

Name: Brise, Theodore
Description: Anarchism and Arbeter Ring, Los Angeles; Yiddish anarchist activists and the Rudolf Rocker Circle.

Name: Brookwood Labor College
Description: Narration by Jon Bloom of slide show on history of Brookwood Labor College and Workers' Education Local 189, with comments by former Brookwood staff and students.

Name: Brorsen, Niki
Description: Family background and growing up in San Francisco and Chicago, 1950s-60s; anti-war work and decision to join Young Socialist Alliance, late 1960s; work as a waitress and activities in restaurant union, 1970s.

Name: Buch, Peter
Description: Immigration from Turkey and youth in Los Angeles; brief involvement in Socialist Zionism, early 1950s; Socialist Workers Party and Young Socialist Alliance, Los Angeles and nationally, 1950s-60s, including involvement in Robert Williams case, responses to Cuban Revolution and Vietnam War.

Name: Burbank, David
Description: Saint Louis radicalism, 1930s; Socialist Party, American Workers Party, Trotskyist movement, Workers Party; CLR James in Missouri; gas workers' unionization.

Name: Burlak, Ann
Description: Rhode Island Labor activities, early 1930s, and her own role as a Communist speaker, activist, organizer in Providence and Pawtucket.
C

Name: Cantor, Fanny & Herman
Description: Immigration to US from Russia and development of social consciousness; growing up in New York's Hell's Kitchen; radicalism and cooperativism, 1920s-30s; reflections on current issues and younger radicals.

Name: Caplowitz, Philip
Description: Immigration; activities of Jewish Communists in unions, 1920s-30s; Yiddish Culture and Yiddishe Kultur Farband, 1930s-present.

Name: Carroll, Wendell
Description: American Youth for Democracy, late 1940s; Independent Socialist League, early 1950s; ISL positions on Korean War, Rosenberg case, Communist Party and McCarthyism, race and civil rights.

Name: Caruso, Pincus
Description: Origins of Labor (Poale) Zionism in Eastern Europe and Caruso's role, early years of century; formation and publication of Yiddishe Kempfer, New York; growth of Poale Zionism in World War I era and brief publication of daily Zionist newspaper; growth of Zionism in 1930s-40s and support of Israel; reflections on failure of Zionists as regards Arab inhabitants, 1930s onward, and about conservative Israeli leadership.

Name: Catholic Worker Conference
Description: Program to honor Dorothy Day and founding of the Catholic Worker; panel comments by John Cort and others on Dorothy Day's character and the influence of the Worker. Trinity College, Worcester, Massachusetts.

Name: Chasanow, Bernard
Description: Narrative translation of part of his 1956 Yiddish autobiography, Days and Years.

Name: Chasanow, Bernard
Description: ILGWU, 1909-1928; Political activist in Russia, 1898-1909.

Name: Chase, Rev. Don
Description: Activities against US intervention in Nicaragua, 1928; Christian Socialism in San Francisco parish, 1930s-50s; interpretation of Liberation Theology, 1970s-80s.

Name: Chernin, Rose
Description: Origins and activities of Los Angeles branch, Committee for the Protection of the Foreign Born, 1940s-1950s; family life, problems and differences with daughter.

Name: Christoffel, Harold
Description: Early union background, 1930s, of former president of United Auto Workers Local 248 (Allis Chalmers), Milwaukee, Wisconsin.

Name: Ciminelli, Helen
Description: Activities of SNPJ (Slovenian Benefit Society) in Fontana, California, 1930s- present; SNPJ role in Henry Wallace campaign.

Name: Citron, Alice
Description: Harlem teacher, 1930s-1940s; Teachers's Union; her dismissal during McCarthy era and struggle for reinstatement.

Name: CCNY Memorial
Description: Recording of Dedication of memorial for 13 CCNY alumni members of the Abraham Lincoln Brigade killed in action in the Spanish Civil War.

Name: Clemente, Edigio
Description: Editor of La Parole, and secretary of Italian Socialist Federation, 1390s.

Name: Cloud, Lucy Ann
Description: Industrial Workers of the World Centralia, Wash. case, 1919, with particular reference to Elmer Smith, IWW attorney.

Name: Cohen, Rose
Description: Recollections of studies at the Jefferson School of Social Science.

Name: Cohen, Joseph & Ruth
Description: On "Carlo" (Jesse Cohen), the cartoonist of the Workers Party, 1940s.

Name: Corey, Olga
Description: Experiences of Louis Fraina/Lewis Corey's daughter; reaction to the movie Reds; reminiscences of father at Antioch College, 1940s; her own union activities.

Name: Cortez, Carlos
Description: Son of Mexican-American activist who joined Industrial Workers of the World after San Diego Free Speech Fight; father's life in Milwaukee, 1920s; mother, German-American Socialist and poet; Cortez' imprisonment during World War II as conscientious objector; role of IWW in Chicago Mexican- American community, 1940s; Cortez' role as artist and speaker for IWW, 1940s-present; anarchism and IWW.

odd.head: General note
odd.p:
Transcript and index available

did.unittitle:
Name: Cowley, Malcolm
Description: Left in the Depression; League of Professional Groups, "Culture and the Crisis," 1932; the proletarian novel; John Reed Clubs; Popular Front; Spanish Civil War; reflections.

Name: Cvetas, Joseph
Description: Family background in SNPJ (Slovenian Benefit Society); fraternal activities as child; fraternalism today.
D

Name: Darcy, Sam
Description: Immigrant background; Communist activities, 1920s; factionalism; Browderism; leaves CP; subsequent activities and reflections. [See also Sam Darcy Papers, Tamiment Library].

Name: Davidson, Saul
Description: "United Front" of various organizations for preservation of Yiddish language in Miami Beach; Davidson as former left activist become mainstream Yiddish activist; reflections on survival of Yiddish.

Name: Davis, Sam
Description: Role of Jewish Left in New Haven, Conn. since 1920s; nature of Jewish community; split of Socialists and Communists, 1920s; Yiddishe Kultur Farband choir and other activities; separation of Morgen Freiheit supporters from Communists and cultural activities in YKUF/Jewish Currents circle.

Name: Deak, Zoltan
Description: Aesthetics of Hungarian-American radical press, Uj Elore and Hungarian Word, 1920s- present; immigration and interest in progressive press; circulation and internal structure of Uj Elore; shrinking of Hungarian-American milieu.

Name: Dean, Jeannette
Description: Background; union activities; radicalism and unions, UE in Newark.

Name: De Leon, Solon
Description: Socialist Party and reformism, 1900-20; Solon's break with Daniel DeLeon; IWW; Industrial Union League and Socialist Labor Party since 1930s.

Name: Delfino, Albina
Description: Italian-American women and the Communist Party, Needle Trades Industrial Union, National Textile Workers Union; CP organizer in Lawrence, Providence, Boston, Corona, N.Y., 1930s-40s.

Name: Dolgoff, Esther
Description: Anarchist women of the 1930s; character of anarchism.

Name: Dongas, Bill
Description: Greek partisan in WWII; immigration struggles in 1950s; Greek publications and radio-Chicago.

Name: Dora
Description: Student radicalism, 1930s; Communist Party; United Electrical Workers; social life and friends.

Name: Dougherty, Pauline
Description: Background in shoe town; college politics in depression; union activity in offices and the Left; McCarthy Era; reflections.

Name: Drake-Raphals, Susan
Description: Workers Party, 1940s and her role in it; C.L.R. James in the 1940s.

Name: Draper, Hal
Description: Role as editor of Labor Action, 1949-1958; problems of "Shachtmanite" group and analysis offered in LA; developing writers and subjects for newspaper ; political disintegration of group; Draper moves to Berkeley.

Name: Duda, Walter
Description: Lithuanian-American Left activities around Connecticut's Brass Valley, 1920s-50s.

Name: Dudley, Jane
Description: Dance and left politics; New Dance group; Martha Graham; civil rights.

Name: Dunayevskaya, Raya
Description: Trotsky and Trotskyism, 1930s; Johnson- Forest group, 1940s; coal strikes of 1949-50 and origins of "Marxist-Humanist" organization News and Letters.
E

Name: Edwards, George
Description: Political origins as Garveyite, 1920s; social life in 1920s-30s; semiprofessional football player, prohibition-era gangster, factory worker; Communist organizer, Kansas-Nebraska district, 1930s-40s; disillusionment in Communist movement, Oakland, Ca., 1940s-50s; life in Ghana, 1950s-60s.

did.unittitle:
Name: Edwards, Herb
Description: Life in Wisconsin lumber, early 1900s and Industrial Workers of the World; Elmer Smith, repression of IWW; San Quentin; IWW ebb.

Name: Edwards, Hoddee
Description: Background in Boston Jewish community, 1920s-30s; Communist activist in California, 1940s; women's rights crusader, People's World, 1949; life in Ghana, 1950s-60s; private life since.

Name: Epstein, Melech
Description: Recollections of experiences since his immigration from Warsaw in 1913, including editorship of Freiheit; comments on Yiddish publications and Jewish life in America, the Cold War, Israel, and current (early 1970s) American politics.

Name: Epstein, Virginia
Description: Born 1885; background in Dallas, Texas as child of mixed Episcopalian-Jewish marriage; in New York from 1908, Socialist Party, 1910s; Communist Party from 1920s; American Council on US-Soviet Friendship; Committee of American Women; local political activities in Queens, N.Y.

Name: Evelyn, S.
Description: Youth in Connecticut and the Bronx; Young Communist League, 1930s; anti-Nazi and pro-Republican Spain activity in Yorkville.
F

Name: Faber, Seymour
Description: Radical Zionism; Johnson-Forest Tendency; Detroit 1930s-60s.

odd.head: General note

did.unittitle:
Name: Felhaber, Elmer
Description: Minnesota newspaper unionism, 1930s; CIO and Communist Party; Ohio Left after WWII; visits abroad.

Name: Ferguson, Duncan
Description: (Memorial Meeting) Eulogy by Harry Ring, of sculptor and activist in Socialist Workers Party, 1940s-70s.

Name: Ferlinghetti, Lawrence
Description: Beat Generation in retrospect; San Francisco avant-garde arts and anarchism, 1940s and early 1950s; formation of City Lights book- store and publishing company; tasks for artists in modern world.

Name: Figueredo, Joseph
Description: Portuguese-American Left in New Bedford and Fall River, Mass., 1930s-40s; political origins in strikes of 1920s and Communist role; lack of formal fraternal and cultural structure and absence of regular Portuguese- language Communist press; use of local radio; Cold War pressures, 1940s, and departure to San Francisco; activities in ILWU, 1950s-present.

Name: Fisher, Morris
Description: Labor Zionism and Workmen's Circle, 1930s; Jewish Socialist Farband, led by L. Siegel with Fisher as assistant; Israel and Yiddish; Miami Beach Yiddishkayt today.

Name: Foner, Henry
Description: Driven out of teaching, late 1940s; industry and union activities, 1948-present; Communist Party and Ben Gold.

Name: Friedland, William
Description: Cultural perspective in Workers Party; role of music in Friedland's life and creation of record, Songs for Sectarians; college teaching and sympathy for antiwar students, 1960s.

Name: Friedland, Isadore & Fishgold Max
Description: Union activities and the Left, 1930s- 1950s.
G

Name: Gale, Mary
Description: Growing up in East New York and Queens in 1910s-20s; ILGWU, 1920s-30s; Scottsboro case, American Labor Party; family and home life in relation to her work and political activism.

Name: Gardners, Alex & Faye; Kantor, Abe & Hodes, Hyman
Description: Jewish and Italian radicalism, 1930s-1950s; Unemployed councils; Workers' Club; WPA; Garibaldi Clubs; work with Marcantonio as his campaign manager, union activities.

Name: Garlin, Sender
Description: Personal background in Socialist Party, 1910s; working at the Daily Worker, 1920s-30s; atmosphere of newspaper; role of humor at Daily Worker.

Name: Gellert, Hugo
Description: Cartoonist adn graphic artist. Immigration from Hungary to US, and return of John Reed; cartoonist, Massesmagazine; commercial work for New Yorkerand New York newspapers, 1920s-30s; role as cartoonist in Hungarian-American Left newspaper, Uj Elore.

Name: Gerson, Sophie Melvin
Description: Background and youth in the Ukraine, Massachusetts, New York; Young Communist League, 1920s; Passaic and Gastonia textile strikes.

Name: Giganti. Joseph
Description: Italian-American Communist newspaper, Il Lavoratore, editorial staff and theatrical commentary; nature of Italian-American Left milieu in Chicago, 1920s; expulsion from Communist movement; early Trotskyism; "Oehlerite" faction of Trotskyists, and their Chicago activity, 1930s; expulsion from Ohelerites and further political commitments.

Name: Goldberg, Itche
Description: Jewish cultural movement, and role of her humor in Jewish cultural life.

Name: Goldstein, Mollie
Description: Communist Party, 1930s; women's organizations; price and rent protests, Brooklyn and the Bronx.

Name: Goldstein, Nina
Description: Early life in Russia, Canada; work and political life in Brownsville and East Flatbush, Brooklyn, 1920s-30s; Communist Party, Freiheit, International Workers Order; Russian War Relief and aid to Israel, 1940s; Jewish cultural movement, Miami Beach.

Description: On C.L.R. James, 1920s-60s; Workers Party, 1940s; Trotskyism, anti-Stalinism, neo-conservatism, Pan-Africanism; Eric Williams.

Name: Gordon, Michael

Name: Grandma was an Activist
Description: Radio series on women radicals of 1930s, in six half-hour parts, produced from OHAL interviews for WBAI-FM; includes excerpts from interviews with Louise Thompson, Jane Dudley, Alice Dodge Wolfson, Meridel LeSueur et. al.

Name: Grant, Leah-Dillon
Description: Yiddish literary milieu in 1920s and role of interviewee's uncle, A.M. Dillon; Johnson-Forest Tendency, its leaders and activities, 1940s; cultural perspectives.

Name: Greenberg, Samuel
Description: Yiddish culture and the Left; Los Angeles Yiddish Left from the 1930s-present.

Name: National Guardian Forum
Description: New Communist Party; criticism of 1960s' politics; history of the class struggle.
H

Name: Halonen, Oive
Description: Finnish-American radicalism, Minnesota and Oregon, 1910s-30s; participation in Spanish Civil War as member of Abraham Lincoln Brigade; experiences as Seattle machinist, 1940s-60s.
